article:
'William of Sherwood' (or Shyreswood, Shireswood) (1190â1249) was a medieval
English Scholastic philosopher, logician and teacher.

Little is known of his life, but he is thought to have studied in Paris, as a
master at Oxford in 1252, treasurer of Lincoln from 1254/8 onwards, and a rector
of Aylesbury.

He was the author of two books which were an important influence on the
development of Scholastic logic: Introductiones in Logicam (Introduction to
Logic), and [[Syncategorematic term|Syncategoremata]]. These are the first known
works to deal in a systematic way with what is now called supposition theory,
known in William's time as the logica moderna.
